string-array.name: gallery_array
string-array.item: Female tiger mosquito. Tiger mosquitoes (1) are small and black with white stripes, (2) they have a white stripe on the head and thorax, and (3) they have white stripes on the abdomen and legs. There are other similar insects, so it is important to avoid confusing them!
Female tiger mosquito. Note the stripes on the abdomen. Remember that the tiger mosquito is very small, not more than 5 mm (including legs, about half the size of a 1 cent coin).
Female tiger mosquito ready to bite. Note the white stripe on the head and thorax, and the stripes on the legs .
Female tiger mosquito biting. Note the characteristic white stripe on the head and thorax.
Female tiger mosquito biting. Note the characteristic white stripe on the head and thorax.
Two female tiger mosquitoes biting. Remember that only the females bite. Tiger mosquitoes usually bite during the day (not when it\'s dark) and they usually bite legs.
Female tiger mosquito biting. The blood that accumulates in the abdomen will trigger the laying of eggs.

Tiger mosquito laying eggs. Note the eggs\' dark color and elongated shape. The eggs are so small that they are almost invisible to the naked eye. Remember that the tiger mosquito lays eggs in small containers, on dry walls by stagnant and dirty water.

Tiger mosquito larvae (more elongated) and pupae (more rounded). Note that they are aquatic. The larvae emerge from the eggs when they are covered with water and eventually make the transition to pupae.
Tiger mosquito larvae (more elongated) and pupae (more rounded). Remember that to keep tiger mosquitos out of your home you need to avoid having standing water in which the larvae can develop!
Two tiger mosquito pupae. This is the phase in which metamorphosis occurs, and the adult mosquito emerges from the pupa and enters the aerial environment.

Use current location or select location from map?
Are you sure you want to delete this report?
Does it have stagnant water inside?
Have you seen mosquito larvae (not necessarily tiger mosquito) inside?
Tiger mosquitoes have white stripes on their abdomens and legs.
Is it small and black with white stripes?
Tiger mosquitoes are small and black with white stripes.
Does it have a white stripe on the head and thorax?
Does it have white stripes on the abdomen and legs?

HELP:
Think you\'ve found a tiger mosquito? Fill out this report and send in your data. Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.

  • Description: The questions here will help you decide if what you\'ve found is really a tiger mosquito.

  • Location: Choose current location if you are still in the place where you found the mosquito. (Make sure you have GPS enabled on your phone.) Otherwise, select the mosquito\'s location on the map.

  • Photo(s): Take a photo of the mosquito now or attach one from a file.

  • Notes: Add a note if you want to send additional information about your finding.

Once sent, you can view and edit your report on your phone by selecting the map activity from the main screen and then clicking on a report icon. The information you submit will also be published map on a public tiger mosquito map at www.atrapaeltigre.com .

HELP:
Found a public space where you think the tiger mosquito can breed? Fill out this report and send in your data. Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.

  • Description: The questions here will help you decide if what you\'ve found is really a tiger mosquito breeding site.

  • Location: Choose current location if you are still at the site. (Make sure you have GPS enabled on your phone.) Otherwise, select the site\'s location on the map.

  • Photo(s): Take a photo of the site now or attach one from a file.

  • Notes: Add a note if you want to send additional information about your finding.

Once sent, you can view and edit your report on your phone by selecting the map activity from the main screen and then clicking on a report icon. The information you submit will also be published map on a public tiger mosquito map at www.atrapaeltigre.com .

Tiger mosquito larvae and pupae live in deposits and small containers of standing water that is dirty (and has no fish). Examples: storm drains, fountains, basins, wells, buckets, etc..

Tiger mosquito larvae are generally not found on the beach or in rivers, lakes, ponds, or wetlands (although you may find other types of larvae in these places).
The larvae and pupae need stagnant water and organic matter (food) to survive. Avoid letting water accumulate in or around you home.

The mosquito larvae are easy to recognize. They are elongated and smaller than a 1-cent coin, and they swim and do pirouettes in the water. They move a lot and come to the surface of the water to breathe.

Tiger mosquitoes have a white stripe on the head and thorax.
Use this space to include a note or comments if necessary.
The photographs in Tigatrapp were provided by R. Eritja (www.eritja.com).

AtrapaelTigre.com is a citizen science project coordinated by the ICREA-Movement Ecology Lab at the Centre for Advanced Studies of Blanes (CSIC).

The project is being implemented in collaboration with CSIC scientific communication officers (Associate Vice President for Scientific Culture, Balearic Islands Delegation, Catalonia Delegation, and Valencia Delegation) and the University of Murcia.

The project is co-financed by the Spanish Foundation for Science and Technology (FECYT) and the Recercaixa research grant program within the framework of the project "Citizen Science: education and research". Bloom is collaborating in the fight against the tiger mosquito by also sponsoring the AtrapaelTigre.com project.

The project also has the support of several other public and private institutions.

All of the photos used in Tigatrapp were provided by R. Eritja (www.eritja.com) .
Copyright © 2013, 2014 John R.B. Palmer, Aitana Oltra, Joan Garriga ansd Frederic Bartumeus

Want to help study and monitor tiger mosquitoes in Spain? Tigatrapp lets you share information about mosquito breeding sites and adult mosquito sightings with researchers and the public. It also brings you the latest tiger mosquito news and helps you learn how to keep this insect out of your home.

  1. Learn about the tiger mosquito and its breeding sites. You\'ll find everything you need in the app and on the project website.
  2. Share data. Send reports when you spot adult tiger mosquitoes or breeding sites in public spaces. You will be helping to build the first-ever crowdsourced map of tiger mosquitoes in Spain.
  3. Store and edit your own data in your phone or tablet from the app\'s mapping screen.
  4. Much more -- from volunteering for special tiger mosquito missions to keeping up with the latest news about tiger mosquitoes and the AtrapaelTigre.com project.

Explore Tigatrapp and if you have any questions, just check the help page or visit www.atrapaeltigre.com

To participate, you must agree to the terms of use and privacy policy posted at www.atrapaeltigre.com/terms_of_use. If you have read and agree to these terms, please indicate your consent by submitting the form below:


CONSENT FORM

(FECYT 2013 Call; Project FCT-13-7019) Design and implementation of a system for citizen-driven tiger mosquito monitoring and alerts: Science and society (Atrapa el Tigre 2.0)

I have read and agree to the terms of use and privacy policy posted at www.atrapaeltigre.com/terms_of_use.

I understand that I must be an adult or supervised by an adult to participate in the project AtrapaelTigre.com through the Tigatrapp application.

I understand that Tigatrapp collects and may share with third parties or the general public the following information:

  • All of the reports I submit on breeding sites, adult mosquito sightings, and tiger mosquito missions. This includes my precise location when submitting each report, and any photographs, notes or other information or media that I attach.
  • Coarse information about my locations at other times, sampled at random time intervals. This information is collected in order to build a map of the geographic areas that you are monitoring for tiger mosquitoes, and to learn more about the routes along which tiger mosquitoes may be spreading.
  • Information about my phone model, battery power, language settings, and Tigatrapp installation. This information is used to help the research team improve the app.

I understand that Tigatrapp does not collect information about identified or identifiable individuals, according to the Organic Law 15/1999. I understand that it is my responsibility to make appropriate use of Tigatrapp and never to collect or send through Tigatrapp images in which people may be identified or any other personal images or information. I agree not to use Tigatrapp in an improper or unlawful manner or to use it for any purpose other than that for which it is intended.

I understand that mobile phone use while driving is prohibited and may increase the risk of accidents, death or damages. I understand that I must not use the application or otherwise use my cell phone in any way while driving, and I agree not to do so. I also understand that safety is the top priority in all aspects of this project and I agree to use my phone at all times in a safe manner.

I understand that all of the information I share through Tigatrapp will become part of a dataset owned by the AtrapaelTigre.com project team, and that the project team will use this dataset for scientific research on ecology, the environment, and public health. I also understand that the AtrapaelTigre.com project team may distribute this dataset to third parties or the general public in accordance with the terms of use and privacy policy posted at www.atrapaeltigre.com/terms_of_use.

I understand that the objective of this citizen science research project is to study the presence and spread of the Asian tiger mosquito , as well as issues related to citizen participation and citizen science. I understand that I will not receive any compensation for my participation and that I cannot cancel or modify information once I have shared it, but that this information can be in no way associated with my person. I understand that reasonable measures will be taken to protect my privacy in all the information submitted as part of the project.

By consenting to these terms, I declare that I have reached the age of majority in the jurisdiction within which I will be participating, and that I have read and understand that:

A. My participation is voluntary and I may withdraw my consent and discontinue participation in the project at any time. My refusal to participate will not result in any penalty. My participation is subject to the conditions of this consent form and the terms of use and privacy policy posted at www.atrapaeltigre.com/terms_of_use.

B. My consent does not imply the waiver of any rights or release the CSIC, its agents, or the project researchers of from liability for negligence.

I hereby consent to participate in this research project under the conditions of this consent form and the terms of use and privacy policy posted at www.atrapaeltigre.com/terms_of_use.

Tigatrapp, versió 1.0

Tigatrapp is an application that harnesses the power of citizen scientists and new technologies to investigate the spread of Tiger Mosquitoes in Spain. The application was developed by the Movement Ecology Laboratory of the Center for Advanced Studies of Blanes (CEAB-CSIC). The code is drawn in part from Space Mapper (John R.B. Palmer), and the Human Mobility Project (Chang Y. Chung, Kathleen Li and Necati E. Ozgencil). The Tigatrapp code is freely available from the Movement Ecology Lab.

Copyright © 2013 John R.B. Palmer, Aitana Oltra, Joan Garriga and Frederic Bartumeus

PARTICIPATE

Participate in the study and monitoring of tiger mosquitoes in Spain by sending repors on breeding sites and adult tiger mosquito sightings. Get the latest news and learn to combat tiger mosquitoes in your home.

Learn about the tiger mosquito

Learn to recognize the tiger mosquito and make sure not to confuse it with other mosquitoes. Learn about the mosquito\'s life cycle and breeding places. The app and the project website AtrapaelTigre.com contain all the information necessary for gathering quality data.

Begin sharing data

Use the "PARTICIPATE" buttons on the main screen to send reports on breeding sites in public spaces and sightings of adult tiger mosquitoes. You\'ll find detailed information by clicking the information (i) icons.

Keep your information updated

Use the "MY MAP" button to view your reports and edit them if necessary to update or correct information.

Volunteer for missions

If you are using the Android version of Tigatrapp, you will be notified of special missions by an icon appearing on your device\'s status bar. You can volunteer for mission at any time, postpone it for later, or delete it from your device. Check pending missions from the menu options on the main screen.

Explore other options

Explore the options menus on each screen to access features. Change the base map style, share the app with friends, or check the latest news from AtrapaelTigre.com.  

YOUR DATA

The information you submit is sent to the Centre for Advanced Studies of Blanes (CEAB-CSIC), which is coordinating the AtrapaelTigre.com project. The data will be used to learn more about the spread of tiger mosquitoes in Spain and may be shared with third parties or the public.   Tigatrapp also collects coarse information on your location at random times throughout the day in order to generate a map of the areas being monitored by Tigatrapp users, and to learn about the routes along which tiger mosquitoes may be spreading. These locations are masked by placing rounding your actual location to the nearest 0.5 degrees latitude and longitude, making it possible to know that you were in an area roughly the size of XXX, but impossible to know where you were in that area. The locations are linked only to your randomly-generated user ID, and no personally-itentifying information is collected. Parts of the data you share will be automatically published on the web map at AtrapaelTigre.com. At any time you can delete, edit and update the data on this map from your phone by clicking the "MY MAP" button on the main screen and selecting a report.  

ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS

Check the website or contact info@atrapaeltigre.com for more information.
